content: The Act may be cited as the "Our Nation's Trade, Infrastructure, Mobility, and Efficiency Act of 2007" or the "ON TIME Act of 2007". The growth in international trade, especially containerized trade, is straining the nation's transportation network and causing traffic congestion near major U.S. international gateways. Between 2000 and 2005, the value of international trade increased from $2 trillion to $2.6 trillion, and the number of containerized trade shipments rose from 59 million to 81 million 20-foot equivalent units. Between 2000 and 2005, international trade value grew from $2 trillion to $2.6 trillion, with containerized trade shipments increasing from 59 million to 81 million 20-foot equivalent units. The United States is part of the World Trade Organization and has agreed to 11 free trade agreements, with negotiations ongoing for 4 more agreements. Traffic congestion in the United States is worsening, leading to Americans wasting billions of hours in traffic and spending billions of dollars on extra fuel each year. Additionally, over 200 freight bottlenecks are causing economic losses and delays in the goods movement industry annually. The goods movement industry incurs $8 billion in economic losses annually and 243 million hours of lost productivity due to traffic congestion. Government investments of $235 billion in 2006, $304 billion in 2015, and $472 billion in 2030 are needed to maintain and improve transportation systems for economic productivity. The government must invest $288 billion in 2006, $368 billion in 2015, and $561 billion in 2030 to address transportation needs and reduce freight congestion along trade corridors. The goal is to increase economic productivity and develop corridors to support freight movement. The government must invest billions to address transportation needs and reduce freight congestion along trade corridors to increase economic productivity and enhance the quality of life for citizens. Establishment and collection of national trade gateway corridor fee. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a national trade gateway corridor fee on imported articles in the United States, amounting to .075 percent of the article's value or $500, whichever is less. The Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, will assess and collect a fee for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors for imported articles in the United States, based on the article's value or $500, whichever is less. The Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with Homeland Security and Commerce, will establish a fee for transportation trade corridors for imported articles in the US. Amounts received will be deposited in a specific account, and the fee will not apply after fiscal year 2017. The Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with Homeland Security and Commerce, will establish a national trade gateway corridor fee on exported articles from the US. The fee will be 0.75% of the article's value or $500, whichever is less. The Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with Homeland Security and Commerce, will assess and collect a fee for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors for exported articles from the US. The fee will be based on the article's value as defined in regulations, and amounts received will be deposited to the United States. The fee established for transportation trade corridors for exported articles from the US will be deposited in the "National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund" account. The fee will not apply after fiscal year 2017. The "National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund" account will hold fees for transportation trade corridors. The Secretary of Transportation can use the funds for expenditures until October 1, 2018, to fulfill obligations of the United States. SEC. 4. APPORTIONMENT OF FUNDS. The Secretary of Transportation allocates 2 percent of funds from the National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund for administrative expenses related to collecting fees on imports and exports. After this set-aside, the remaining funds are apportioned to State departments for implementing the Act. The Trade Gateway Corridor Fund, established by section 3, provides grants to State departments of transportation for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors for Customs ports of entry. The grants are allocated based on the fees collected for each Customs port of entry in the preceding fiscal year. The Trade Gateway Corridor Fund allocates grants to State departments of transportation for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors for Customs ports of entry. The funds are apportioned among states based on lane miles of Federal-aid. The Trade Gateway Corridor Fund allocates grants to State departments of transportation for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors for Customs ports of entry. 50 percent of the apportionment is based on the total lane miles of Federal-aid highways in the transportation trade corridor in each state compared to all states, while the other 50 percent is based on the total vehicle miles traveled on lanes on Federal-aid highways. The Trade Gateway Corridor Fund grants State departments of transportation funds for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors for Customs ports of entry. The allocation is based on the total vehicle miles traveled on lanes on Federal-aid highways in each state compared to all states. Amounts granted for eligible projects in transportation trade corridors are available for a specific period. Funds allocated by the Department of Transportation for projects in transportation trade corridors must be used within 6 years. Any unspent funds after this period will be distributed to other states for similar projects at the Secretary's discretion. SEC. 5. PROJECT SELECTION AND ELIGIBILITY. The Secretary of Transportation must issue project selection guidelines for State departments of transportation to follow in selecting eligible projects for grants under this Act, including consulting with various stakeholders during the process. The Secretary of Transportation must issue project selection guidelines for State departments of transportation to follow in selecting eligible projects for grants under this Act. This includes consulting with regional planning organizations, public and private freight shippers, and providers of freight transportation services, adhering to planning processes, developing a transparent selection process, and rating proposed projects accordingly. The Secretary of Transportation must develop guidelines for State departments to rate proposed projects for grants under this Act. The State department of transportation must clearly identify the basis for rating projects under the developed process. The Secretary of Transportation must develop guidelines for State departments to rate proposed projects for grants under this Act. The State department of transportation must clearly identify the basis for rating projects under the developed process. SEC. 6. GRANT PROGRAM. The Secretary of Transportation may grant funds to State departments for projects in transportation trade corridors. Grants are only for eligible projects meeting construction standards for highways on a Federal-aid system. The Federal share of funding is determined for each project. The Federal share of funding for eligible transportation projects under this Act is 80 percent, with the non-Federal share not allowed to come from other Federal funds. Wage rates are set according to prevailing standards. The prevailing wage rate for eligible transportation projects funded under this Act must adhere to Section 113 of title 23, United States Code. SEC. 7. TRANSPORTATION TRADE CORRIDORS. The Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, shall establish transportation trade corridors for Customs ports of entry, with boundaries not exceeding 300 miles and potentially spanning multiple contiguous states. The Secretary of Transportation may establish a single transportation trade corridor for multiple ports of entry located close to each other, with boundaries not exceeding 300 miles and focused on motor vehicle and cargo movements related to international trade. The deadline for establishing proposed corridors is 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Transportation must publish proposed transportation trade corridor boundaries within 180 days of the Act's enactment. A 45-day comment period will follow for public input, with hearings as needed. Final corridors must be established within one year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Transportation must publish the boundaries of transportation trade corridors within one year of the Act's enactment. Periodic reviews and modifications may be conducted before each fiscal year to ensure the existence of a transportation trade corridor. The Secretary of Transportation must establish transportation trade corridors for each Customs port of entry where fees were collected in the previous fiscal year. The corridors' boundaries must align with the objectives of the Act. The Secretary of Transportation must issue regulations within one year of the Act's enactment to carry out its objectives. Authorization of appropriations is also included in the Act. The National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund is authorized to receive appropriations for fiscal years 2009 through 2018. Funds deposited in the Fund can be used for highway projects, with grants approved by the Secretary considered as contractual obligations of the Government. Authorization for these funds becomes available on October 1 of the fiscal year they are allocated. The National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund is authorized to receive appropriations for fiscal years 2009 through 2018. Eligible projects include construction or improvements to publicly owned intermodal freight transfer facilities. The National Trade Gateway Corridor Fund is authorized for appropriations from 2009 to 2018 for eligible projects, such as construction or improvements to intermodal freight transfer facilities. The term "Federal-aid highway" and "State" are defined in the legislation. The term "State" in the United States Code refers to any of the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. The term "State department of transportation" is defined under section 101 of title 23, United States Code. The term "United States" encompasses the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico.
